title: [GAMEPLAY] Azir Shifting Sands has defective soldier targeting. 100% reproducible + with video
body:
I got done testing out Azir in some custom games, and I noticed I was having some trouble with casting Azir's Shifting Sands on my soldiers, particularly at longer ranges.

**Tested Map:** Summoner's Rift (likely to exist on other maps)
**Note:** All spellcasts performed with quickcasting.

**Normal circumstance:** When a soldier is standing outside of Azir's cast range of Shifting Sands, and Shifting Sands is cast within the soldier's attack radius, Azir will move toward the soldier until the soldier is in casting range, at which point Azir will dash toward the soldier. 

**Incident:** There exists a casting deadzone for Shifting Sands within the soldier attack radius ONLY while the target soldier's body is outside of the Shifting Sands' cast range on initial cast. When Shifting Sands is cast in this "deadzone", Azir automatically dashes to the nearest "active" soldier (this does imply a soldier count greater than one). Shifting Sands will not go on cooldown when this occurs. 

The deadzone is slightly smaller than a semi-circle, with the same radius as the soldier's attack radius, and is aligned in such a way that its tangent forms a right-angle with the tether that Azir maintains with the soldier. In this way, the deadzone is always facing toward Azir. ***Attached to this post is a crude visual representation of this 'deadzone'.*** 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**Incident with 1 soldier:** When Shifting Sands is cast in this deadzone while the soldier is outside of the cast range, Azir will not move toward the soldier until its body is in cast range. Instead, Azir will either stand still or stutter step one time. 

Repro steps:
1.) Cast Arise! to place a soldier
2.) Walk away from the soldier so that the soldier's body is outside of the cast range of Shifting Sands, but not so far that the soldier disappears
3.) Cast Shifting Sands into the 'deadzone' as shown in the attached 'leaguebug2.jpg' picture
4.) Watch Azir either take no action at all, or stutter

This is demonstrated in the video provided here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=faQpbBoXCk4
First action test shows the incident with 1 soldier. Second action test shows the appropriate action without incident. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**Incident with 2 soldiers:** Suppose two soldiers are out on the field. 'Soldier 1' is in the cast range of Shifting Sands, but 'Soldier 2' is not in the cast range of Shifting Sands. 'Soldier 2' has the deadzone within his attack radius. If Azir casts Shifting Sands in the deadzone of 'Soldier 2', Azir will automatically dash to 'Soldier 1'. If 'Soldier 1' is either out of the cast range as well, or is inactive, Azir will dash to neither soldier and will stutter forward one time.

Repro steps:
1.) Cast Arise twice, spacing out the soldiers a fair amount
2.) Position yourself in such a way that one soldier's body is in the cast range of Shifting Sands, but the other is not 
3.) Cast Shifting Sands in the 'deadzone' of the soldier who is outside of the cast range
4.) Watch Azir dash toward the soldier that is in the cast range

This is demonstrated in the video provided here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uo8w9JQXoyY
First action test shows the incident with 2 soldiers. Second action test shows the appropriate action without incident.

If both 'Soldier 1' and 'Soldier 2' are outside of the cast range of Shifting Sands (therefore, both have a deadzone), when casting in the deadzone of either one, Azir will stutter toward the nearest of the two without actually dashing. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**Incident with 3 soldiers (1/2):** Suppose three soldiers are out on the field. 'Soldier 3' will be standing outside of the cast range of Shifting Sands, but 'Soldiers 1+2' are in the cast range. 'Soldier 3' will have the deadzone in his attack radius. If Azir casts Shifting Sands in the deadzone of 'Soldier 3', Azir will only stutter forward.

Repro steps:
1.) Cast Arise three times, spacing out the soldiers a fair amount
2.) Position yourself in such a way that two soldiers' body is in the cast range of Shifting Sands, but the body of the third soldier is not
3.) Cast Shifting Sands in the 'deadzone' of the soldier who is outside of the cast range
4.) Watch Azir stutter and not do anything else

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**Incident with 3 soldiers (2/2):** Suppose three soldiers are out on the field. 'Soldier 3' will be standing outside of the cast range of Shifting Sands, 'Soldier 2' is inactive (but slightly closer to Azir than 'Soldier 3' is), and 'Soldier 1' is active. 'Soldier 3' will have the deadzone in his attack radius. If Azir casts Shifting Sands in the deadzone of 'Soldier 3', Azir will dash to 'Soldier 1', who is active.

Repro steps:
1.) Cast Arise three times, spacing out the soldiers a fair amount
2.) Position yourself in such a way that two soldiers' body are outside the cast range of Shifting Sands, but the body of the third soldier is inside
3.) Cast Shifting Sands in the 'deadzone' of the furthest soldier who is outside of the cast range
4.) Watch Azir dash to the active soldier instead

The difference between these 2 instances with 3 soldiers is that Azir's behavior changes depending on how many active soldiers are out. When 3 soldiers are out and you cast Shifting Sands in the deadzone of the furthest soldier:
1 active soldier = Azir will dash to that active soldier
2 active soldiers = Azir will stutter and do nothing else
3 inactive soldiers = Azir will stutter and do nothing else

The video provided here shows the incident with 3 soldiers when 2 are active: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eXJGuXD7wJI
First action test shows the incident when casting Shifting Sands in the deadzone. Second action test shows the appropriate action without incident.

I currently do not have video of the incident with 3 soldiers when only 1 is active, as the custom game ended when I was in the middle of recording this instance and didn't capture the incident. I'll add the video when I get the chance to do another custom with Azir.

Let me know if additional information is needed regarding this bug.

replies.body: Wow. This has to be one of THE best player bug report I've seen since I started at Riot. Also forwarded to the Azir QA.

It's inspired me to save up for a capture card to hopefully do the same thing...

Now how expensive are those things again?
Not sure if joking, but you can download many capture programs for free, like fraps.
Really? I literally didn't know this and thought it was some expensive program from Best Buy or something.

Nope, Just google "fraps" and it will be the first thing.  Fraps tends to lower framerate on lower end computers though.  Conveniently it also has the second use of showing the fps in the corner of the game you're playing.

When you download and start to use Fraps in conjunction with League, the default "record" hotkey for Fraps is F9. Incidentally, F9 also locks your screen in League, to where you can't scroll your screen around. Be sure to undo this hotkey in -game so that you don't have restricted movement while recording.
f9? really? mine was always Y
Apparently. In all the videos in this post, you'll see how my screen has the red border while I'm recording.
